div.sent: We know that energy is the ability for doing work.
Energy has many different forms.
It transforms from one form to another.
For example, heat boils water and produces steam.
This steam drives engine.
Railway engine carries men and materials from one place to another.
Thus much work is done.
The steam engine converts heat energy into mechanical energy.
Again rub your two palms strongly for a number of times.
You will feel your palms getting hot.
Here, heat has been produced from mechanical energy.
When an electric bulb is switched on, the electric energy transforms into light and heat energy.
Therefore, heat has the ability of doing work.
Heat can be transformed into other forms of energy.
Also many other forms of energy can be transformed into eat.
So heat is a form of energy.
The energy, which roduces the sensation of hot and cold, is known as heat.
Different scales are used to measure temperature.
Kelvin scale is one of them; Lord Kelvin devised it.
The temperature in this scale is known as degree kelvin or simply kelvin and is denoted by k.
In this scale of temperature ice melts at 273k and water boils at 373k.
To measure a thing, proper unit is required.
For heat also a definite quantity Heat 115 of heat is taken as the unit of heat.
This unit of heat is the quantity of heat required to raise the temperature of one gram of pure water by one degree celsius.
This unit of heat is called calorie.
So, if 1 gm of pure water takes 1 calorie of heat its temperature raises by 1 degree Celsius.
Calorie is a small unit of heat.
Therefore, sometimes kilo-calorie is used as unit of heat.
1 kilo-calorie is the amount of heat which can raise the temperature of 1 kilogram pure water by 1 degree celsius.
Calorie is not taken now a days as the unit of heat.
The reason is, the scientists have decided that different forms of energy must not be measured in different units.
Rather all forms of energy be it heat, light, sound or electricity should be measured by a single unit.
This single unit, which is called S.I unit is joule. 1 calorie of heat is equal to 4.2 joules.
However in many fields calorie and kilo-callore are still used.
The food and nutrition specialists use kilo-calorie to measure energy in food.
A normal adult requires 2200 calorie energy daily from food.
A cup of milk contains 150 kilo-calories while an egg contains 100 kilo-calorie.
The heat required to raise the temperature of 1 gm of pure water by 1 degree calcius is called calorie.
The quantity of heat that can raise the temperature of 1 kilogram of pure water by 1 degree celcius.
Heat is measured by an instrument known as calorimeter.
It is a vessel made of copper or aluminium.
In this vessel hot and cold bodies (like cool water and hot iron) exchange heat.
This exchange of heat is so regulated that no other heat from outside comes in or goes out of the mixture.
All the heat given only by the hot body is taken in by the cold body.
So no other exchange of heat is Heat increases the temperature of a body.
We have seen that the temperature of water increases by 1 degree celsius when 1 calorie of heat is given to it.
You can do an experiment which will answer this question.
In a beaker take 500 gm of water and in another take 500 gm of edible oil.
Both the water and oil will have the room temperature now.
Heat the water in beaker by a spirit lamp for 5 minutes and record its temperature.
Now heat the oil beaker with the same spirit lamp for exactly five minutes.
Record the temperature of the oil.
You will see that although the water and the oil were given the same quantity of heat the rise in temperature is higher for oil.
So we conclude that if equal mass of different substances are given the same quantity of heat, their increase in temperature will be different.
Therefore, the increase in temperature of a substance depends on the material of the body.
The property for which temperatures of different materials increase differently when equal amount of heat is given is called specific heat capacity or specific heat.
Specific heat is the amount of heat that is given to 1 unit mass of the substance to raise its temperature by 1 unit.
In international unit, the heat required to raise the temperature of 1 kilogram substance to 1 degree Kelvin is called specific heat of the substance.
The unit of specific heat is joule per kilogram per Kelvin, in short, Joule/kg-k.
From the table we see that specific heat of water is much higher than any other substance.
Generally the specific heat of liquids is much higher than the specific heat of solids.
The high specific heat of water can be used in various services.
High value of specific heat means that large amount of heat would be required to raise the temperature of substance to a small extent.
For this reason water is used to extinguish fire.
Besides, human body contains 65% to 70% water.
So its specific heat is very high, that means much more heat is required to change our body temperature.
That is why, the temperature of our body does not change usually, it remains almost the same.
Higher specific heat of water helps us keep our body temperature unchanged.
Heat flows from places of higher temperature to places of lower temperature.
We have read this in Class seven.
The process of heat transfer is known as heat transmission.
Put one end of an iron rod on fire.
The other end will be heated soon.
We boil water in a kettle by heating the bottom of the kettle.
If you stand in front of fire, you will feel hot.
Did transmission of heat in these three examples follow the same process?
Say you are sitting at the first row of your class.
Your friend sitting at the last row asked for your science book.
How can you give him the book?
Conduction: In case of iron or other metal made bars if one end is put to fire, the other end gets hot slowly.
Gradually the other end will be so hot that you would not be able to touch it.
Here we see that heat has reached from one end to the other end of the rod through the medium of iron.
But the iron particles did not change their positions.
This process of transmission of heat is called conduction.
We know iron rod is made of many iron molecules.
These molecules are in a state of vibration.
The molecules on the end, which is on fire, takes heat energy and their vibration increases.
But they do not change positions.
Hot Molecules pushes adjacent cold molecules and they are heated in turn and vibrates rapidly.
The molecules do not change their positions in this process.
This process is similar to the first process of sending book to your friend as described above.
The book reached your friend from you through the medium of your class mates, although none of your friends had to change their positions.
Only you and your concerned friends moved hands in giving and taking the book.
A medium is required for heat transfer by conduction.
In a solid body heat usually flows by conduction.
Cold bodies in touch with hotter body are also heated by conduction.
Convection: Take a glass flask.
Put some potassium permanganate granules in it and they settle at the bottom of the flask.
They will colour the water.
Now the flask is heated at the bottom by a gas burner.
You will see that streams of colored water is rising upward through the middle from the flask from its bottom.
You will see another stream flowing down the sides of the flask.
The reason of these movements of streams is that, water at the bottom gets heated, becomes hot and lighter and so moves upward.
These streams of water are called convection current.
Thus hot water from the bottom carries heat above cold water which goes downward and gets itself heated and goes up again.
The process continues until all of the water is equally heated and attains the same temperature.
This process of heat transfer is called convection.
Only liquid and gas substances are heated by convection process.
It is like you taking your book by yourself to your friend as described in the second example above.
So, convection is the process of heat transfer where the heated particles themselves carry heat from the hotter to the colder part of any substance.
Radiation: We know that the sun is the main source of heat.
How does the heat come to the earth from the sun?
The distance between the earth and the sun is 150 million kilometers, but the atmosphere is only extended up to 700-800 kilometer above earth surface.
Beyond this there is empty through this space.
At the last stage the heat passes through the atmosphere.
But the heat from the sun does not warm the atmosphere.
We can know this as we see the atmosphere near the earth surface is hotter than that at a distance from the earth surface.
So without the help of any medium heat comes from the sun to the earth.
This process of heat transference is called radiation.
It is like throwing the book to your friend where you did not take help of any medium.
You feel warm when you stand near fire.
Heat from fire comes to you.
But it does not come to you by conduction, as air can not conduct heat.
It does not come to you by convection either.
Because heated particles go upward, not to the sides.
Therefore it is through radiation only that the heat reaches your body.
In this process heat goes in all directions in a straight line with the velocity of light (velocity of light is 3 10 8m/s).
Actually both heat and light come to earth from the sun by the same process.
Heat from the sun warms the earth surface.
Because of heat anything that obstructs heat becomes hot through heat absorption.
Different bodies have different capacities of heat absorption.
A black body absorbs more heat than a white body Bodies radiated heat at all temperatures.
Radiated heat energy goes in all directions in the form of wave.
This wave is called electromagnetic wave, which travels without the help of any medium.
Light, radiated heat, x-ray all are electro- magnetic waves.
They all move with the speed of light and have all the characteristics of electro-magnetic wave.
It conducts heat rapidly.
On the other hand a glass rod is not heated so quickly.
Heat goes from the hot end to the colder end slowly and it takes time to be heated.
What we understand from this is, conduction capacity of all matters is not the same.
Heat passes easily and quickly through some of them.
They are called good conductors.
Iron, copper, aluminum, gold, silver, in fact, all metals are good conductors of heat.
Again there are matters through which heat goes slowly;
they are called bad conductors of heat.
Glass, rubber, wood, paper, cotton, cork etc. and most liquids and gaseous substances are bad conductor.
There are substances through which heat can not pass at all;
they are called non- conducting materials.
In reality there are no such materials that are perfectly non-conductors.
Very small quantity of heat can pass through them but it is so small that we take them as non-conductors of heat.
Heat 121 Ebonite, polystyrene, thick wood etc. are examples of non-con uctors.
Of course vacuum does not conduct heat at all.
So vacuum is a perfect non-conductor.
We have seen that different materials conduct heat differently.
Heat passes through quickly through some matters and passes slowly through others.
Heat conduction depends on a special property of a substance.
This property is the conductivity.
In other words the special property of the matter on which the rate of heat conduction depends is called thermal conductivity.
The ability of the body to conduct heat through it is also called thermal conductivity.
It can be shown by an experiment that different matters conduct heat differently.
Take three rods (copper, iron, glass) of same length and same diameter.
Keep them on a tripod stand with one ends together and the other ends apart from one another.
Attach a pin to each rod to the scattered end by wax.
Now heat the ends which were kept together by a burner.
After some time you will see that the wax at the other ends begins to melt and the pins are falling down one after another.
Notice that the pins do not fall at the same time but one after another.
The pin attached to copper falls at first, and then the pin attached to iron and finally the pin attached to glass.
The reason for this is, different matters conduct heat differently and copper has the greatest conductivity of the three while glass has the least.
The heat quickly goes to the other end of copper and melts wax, the pin falls.
The process is slower for iron and the slowest for glass.
As because all metals are good conductors of heat, we use cooking utensils made of aluminum, copper or brass.
Heat applied to these pots goes quickly to food ingredients and cooking is done quickly.
So, only small amount of heat is wasted when cooking in metal pots.
The handles of saucepan, pressure cooker, electric iron, and electric kettle is made of ebonite.
As ebonite is a bad conductor of heat, these handles are not heated when the metal parts are heated.
So as we touch the handles we do not burnour hands.
Sometimes hay is used in making thatched roof of a house.
In this roof air particles are confined.
Hay and air are bad conductors of heat.
That is why heat from the sun can not enter the room in summer and the house remains cool.
Again in winter the temperature outside is lower than the temperature inside the house.
Due to the thatched roof the heat inside the house can not go out and it keeps the room warm.
To prevent ice from melting it is covered by sawdust.
Sawdust is bad conductor of heat.
We wear woolen clothes in winter.
Woolen fibre is loosely woven so that air is confined within.
Wool and air being bad conductors of heat do not support heat to go outside from the body.
Thus woolen clothes keep the body warm.
We say woolen cloth is warm.
But the cloth itself is not warm.
It prevents the body heat from going away.
In summer we wear cotton clothes.
Cotton fiber is tightly woven so that little air is confined within these clothes.
Therefore cotton clothes conduct more heat than woolen clothes.
Heat goes out more easily and the body becomes cool when wearing cotton clothes.
We breathe out carbon-di-oxide gas.
This makes the room warm.
We expel the hot air outside and take in fresh cold air inside.
The process is known as ventilation.
You may have seen small holes in the wall below the roof;
these are called ventilators.
Hot air inside the room becomes lighter and goes out of the room through the ventilator and fresh cold air comes inside through the door.
Thus the flow of air is maintained by convection.
Those who study at night using hurricane lamp may have noticed that there are small pores at the top and below the glass chimney.
When the hurricane lamp is lit, air from outside comes in through the pores below and supplies necessary oxygen required to burn the flame.
Thus convection helps the hurricane lamp to burn.
In mills and factories the air inside becomes impure and hot, and this air is expelled out with the help of chimney through convection process.
When radiated heat falls on a surface, a portion of it is reflected, a part is absorbed and the rest is transmitted through the body.
It depends on the nature of the body how much heat will be reflected, how much will be absorbed and transmitted.
White coloured shining bodies reflect more and absorb less heat.
Black bodies with rough surface absorb more heat and reflect less.
Again bodies which absorb more radiate more too.
We generally wear white or light coloured clothes in summer and black or dark coloured clothes in winter.
The reason for that is, white clothes reflect more heat and absorb less.
So they do not get hot easily.
On the other hand black and coloured clothes absorb more heat and get hot quickly.
The inner wall of a tea cup is made white and shining.
As a result it absorbs less heat and heat radiation is small too.
Again the reflected heat comes back to tea so tea remains hot for a longer period.
You may have seen that sometimes the bottom of cooking utensils is coated with mud and burned black.
This rough and black bottom absorbs more heat and this helps cooking quickly.
If the bottom were white and shining it would reflect more heat and cooking will take a long time.
Most of you have seen thermos flask and have used it.
We can keep tea, milk, and soup hot for a certain time.
You can cold water or icecream cold for some time too.
British scientist James Dewar invented thermos flask.
The flask is a double walled glass vessel (fig 10.5).
The space between the walls is evacuated and there is no air in it.
The outer surface of the inner wall and the inner surface of the outer wall is made shining by coating it with silver burnish.
The mouth of the vessel is closed with a cork of rubber or some non-conducting materials.
The double walled vessel is then placed on a spring in a metal casing.
The space between the metal case and glass vessel is then filled with some bad conductor like cotton or felt.
It works well for the following reasons.
The walls are made of glass and the mouth is closed with cork.
Glass and cork are bad conductors of heat.
So less heat can go out to or come in from the outer surrounding by conduction.
The space between the walls is made vacuum so that heat cannot go in or go out by convection.
The walls are silver coloured and shining.
As a result the loss of heat by radiation is minimum.
Thus, all the three possibilities by which heat may come in or go out have been minimized.
These have made possible for hot things to remain hot and cold things to remain cold for a long time in a thermos flask.
To live in this word plant and animal need energy Heat is a form of energy and we use heat in every day life.
We get heat form the sun and from the food we take.
The chemical energy of food is converted into heat energy which makes our body warm and gives us energy to work.
Again by burning wood, coal, gas and kerosene we get heat to use it for cooking.
The motor car, train, steamer, launch, aeroplane etc are runs by engine, which requires energy in the form of heat.
These engines are therefore called heat engines.
Heat engines convert chemical energy of fuel into heat from which we get mechanical energy and energy for movement.
We apply heat to melt iron, copper, aluminium, glass etc. to make things of our daily needs.
Starting from needles to utensils and also many other things of our daily use are being made by melting iron, glass china clay etc.
The paper and pin you use are also made using the heat energy.
Heat is also used to dry wet clothes, paddy, jute etc and to iron clothes.
Many other examples of using heat energy in our daily life may be given.
Can you give some more examples of using heat energy?
